div.l: They wenen þat no Man maye hem begyle
Butte by my þryfte yett schall I blere her eye
For all the Slayghte in her phyllosphye
The more queynte crekes þat they make
The more woll I stele whan þat I take
In stede of Flowre yett woll I yeue hem branne
The gretteste Clarkes bene notte þe wysteste Men
As whylome to þe wolfe þus spake the Mare
Of all her Art counte I notte A tare
Owte of þe durre he goethe Fulle p̉riuelye
Whan þat he saughe his tyme sofftelye
He lokeþe vpp̄e ⁊and downe tille he haþe Founde
The Clarkes horse þ̉er that hitt Stode ybounde
Bihynde the Mylle vnder A leuesel
And to the horse he gothe hym Fayer ⁊and well
He strypeþe of the brydulle ryghte Anone
And whan þe horse was loose he gynneþe gone
Towarde the Fenne þ̉er wylde Mares renne
And Forþe with þroughe þycke ⁊and þroughe þynne
This Myller goeþe agayne no worde he sayde
Butte dothe his note ⁊and with these Clarkes playede
Tille þat her Corne was Fayer ⁊and well ygrounde
And whan the Mele is sackede ⁊and ybounde
This Iohn gothe owte ⁊and Fyndeþe his horse awaye
And gan to Crye harrow ⁊and wayleawaye
Ower horse is loste Aleyn For goddes bones
Step̄e on thy Feete come of Man atte oonesoonesones
Alas ower wardeyne haþe his palfraye lorne
This Aleyn all Forgate boþe Mele ⁊and Corne
All was owte of his Mynde his husbandrye
Whatt whylke waye is he gone he gan to crye
The wyfe came lepenge Atte A ren
Sche sayde Alas your horse gothe to the Fenne
With wylde Mares as Faste As he maye go
